content: The House and Senate Armed Services Committees annually review national defense authorization bills with provisions affecting military personnel, retirees, and their families. Differences between the two versions are resolved by a conference committee before enactment. Congressional staff receive numerous requests for information on these bills. This report focuses on personnel-related provisions. The report highlights personnel-related issues in the House and Senate versions of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016. It compares differences between the two versions and summarizes selected highlights of the bill. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016 (FY2016 NDAA) was passed by the House of Representatives on November 5, 2015, and signed by the President on November 25, 2015. The initial bill, H.R. 1735, was passed by both the House and the Senate after the President vetoed an earlier version on October 22, 2015. The President objected to the bill providing more funding for defense-related activities than allowed under spending caps imposed by the Budget Control Act of 2011. The President vetoed the NDAA on October 22, 2015, citing concerns about exceeding defense spending caps set by the Budget Control Act of 2011. He later signed the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which raised spending caps for both defense and nondefense categories. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015 raised spending caps for both defense and nondefense categories, allowing similar budgetary leeway. The revised FY2016 NDAA was passed by the House and Senate after modifications to comply with the new spending caps. The revised FY2016 NDAA was passed by the House and Senate after modifications to comply with new spending caps.
